The flying pilots failure to configure the flaps for a short field takeoff and delayed decision to abort the takeoff, which resulted in a runway overrun.
The pilots decision to abort the takeoff on encountering a wind gust and his landing beyond the end of the runway that resulted in the airplane impacting a ditch collapsing the nose landing gear.
The student pilots inadequate flare resulting in a loss of control during landing with a crosswind and subsequent nose over.
The pilots failure to visually inspect the runway condition before landing, which resulted in a collision with an ice chunk and main landing gear separation during landing.
A total loss of engine power for reasons that could not be determined based on the available information.
The pilots loss of directional control due to a blown tire, which resulted in a runway excursion and impact with terrain.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during landing that resulted in a runway excursion and collision with a pole.

The student pilots failure to maintain control during takeoff in gusty wind conditions and the flight instructors delayed remedial action, which resulted in the airplane colliding with trees and subsequently the ground.

The flight instructors failure to confirm the position of the left engines auxiliary fuel boost pump switch during a simulated engine out procedure, which resulted in an excess amount of fuel in the engine and subsequent partial loss of power during a go-around/rejected landing. Contributing to the accident was the flight instructors failure to maintain control of the airplane, which resulted in a hard landing.

The student pilot's unintentional selection of raising the landing gear instead of the flaps during a touch-and-go landing, and the flight instructor's delayed remedial action, which resulted in the landing gear retracting during the landing roll.
The pilots failure to attain a proper touchdown point on landing, which resulted in a collision with the runway lip.
The pilots failure to maintain airplane control during a simulated engine out landing which resulted in impact with terrain.
The pilot's failure to maintain lateral control during takeoff after an encounter with a gusting wind, which resulted in a wing strike.
The airplane's impact with a deer during takeoff.
A tail rotor blade strike to an undetermined object while practicing approaches to unimproved terrain.
The pilot's failure to maintain directional control during taxiing in crosswind conditions, which resulted in a taxiway excursion and collision with a fence.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during the takeoff roll, which resulted in a ground loop and collision with terrain.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during landing, with a crosswind, which resulted in a runway excursion and subsequent impact with terrain.
The student pilots improper pitch control and landing flare, which resulted in a hard bounce and subsequent porpoised landing.
The Kingair pilots failure to maintain clearance from another airplane while taxiing, which resulted in a ground collision.
The pilots failure to locate the airport which resulted in an approach to a road and subsequent collision with powerlines during a go-around in low light conditions.
The pilots delayed remediation following an aborted takeoff run, which resulted in a runway overrun and collision with trees.
The pilots improper flare during a landing attempt in crosswind conditions, which resulted in a bounced landing and impact with the ground.
The flight instructors delayed remedial action, which resulted in a loss of control during an attempted go-around.

Both pilots failure to maintain control during the landing flare and the flight instructors failure to maintain control during an attempted go-around, in gusting quartering headwind conditions, which resulted in the exceedance of the airplanes critical angle of attack and an aerodynamic stall at low altitude.
The pilots failure to maintain adequate airspeed while maneuvering at low altitude, which resulted in an aerodynamic stall and impact with the ground.
The flight instructors failure to compensate for a downdraft during takeoff, which resulted in a loss of control and collision with terrain.
The pilot's improper flare which resulted in a bounced landing, loss of directional control and collision with terrain.

The flight instructors failure to maintain aircraft control resulting in the exceedance of the gliders critical angle of attack following the breakage of the weak/safety link during a winch launch, which resulted in an aerodynamic stall and spin, and subsequent impact with trees and terrain.
The pilots loss of directional control while landing, which resulted in a landing gear collapse.

The pilots failure to maintain directional control of the airplane during takeoff while operating in gusting wind conditions, which resulted in a runway excursion and subsequent collision with terrain.
The pilots failure to maintain airplane control while on approach in microburst or windshear conditions, which resulted in impact with a runway sign.
The pilot's failure to maintain directional control after an encounter with a windshear during the landing roll, which resulted in a runway excursion.
The student pilots failure to maintain directional control during landing, which resulted in a runway excursion and collision with a runway sign.
The pilots improper landing flare, which resulted in a hard, bounced landing.
The pilots delayed deployment of the landing gear, which resulted in the collapse of the main landing gear.

The pilots failure to review the weather conditions before the flight, which resulted in a loss of directional control during takeoff due to a sudden change in wind direction and speed associated with an approaching thunderstorm.
The pilot receiving instructions failure to maintain directional control during the landing roll, and the flight instructors delayed remedial action.
The student pilots improper landing flare, which resulted in a bounced landing and subsequent loss of directional control.
The student pilots improper landing flare, which resulted in a hard landing and loss of directional control.
The pilots failure to maintain clearance from a ditch, which resulted in impact with terrain.
The pilots failure to maintain yaw control during landing which resulted in a loss of tail rotor effectiveness.
The pilots failure to attain a proper touchdown point, which resulted in the airplane contacting the ground short of the runway.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control of the airplane during landing, resulting in a runway excursion and collision with an airport sign.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during the takeoff roll.
The pilots loss of directional control during landing.
An in-flight separation of the control stick from the torque tube assembly, which resulted in a loss of directional control during the landing roll and subsequent on-ground collision.
The pilots inadequate performance planning and decision to continue the takeoff which, resulted in a runway overrun and collision with terrain.
A total loss of engine power due to the pilots failure to premix the two-cycle oil/gasoline mixture, which resulted in a forced landing in a field and collision with terrain.

The pilots improper landing flare while making a power off practice autorotative landing. Contributing was the decreased visual cues provided by the recently paved runway during the night landing conducted with the aid of night vision goggles.
The pilot's distraction due to adjusting the radio while taxing at night, which resulted in a taxiway excursion and subsequent impact with terrain.
The flight instructors failure to maintain aircraft control during the landing flare and subsequent attempted go-around with a strong quartering crosswind.
The pilots failure to extend the landing gear during landing and the check pilots inadequate supervision.
The pilots failure to use the landing checklist and to extend the landing gear, which resulted in a gear-up landing.

The pilots inadequate decision to continue the takeoff after sufficient airspeed was not attained and his failure to maintain aircraft control while maneuvering to avoid obstructions, which resulted in a collision with the ground.
The pilots failure to maintain airplane control during a crosswind landing which resulted in an impact with terrain.
The pilots inability to maintain directional control during landing roll due to a flat tire.
The pilot's exceedance of the airplane's critical angle of attack during a go-around, which resulted in an aerodynamic stall and subsequent impact with terrain.
The pilots failure to maintain proper airspeed on approach resulting in an extended touchdown, bounced landing, and runway excursion.
The pilots improper flight control inputs which resulted in a loss of directional control and a nose-over.
The pilots loss of directional control while taxiing at high speed, which resulted in a ground loop.
The pilots high flare and failure to execute a go-around which resulted in a hard landing and runway excursion.
The pilot's loss of directional control while landing, which resulted in a runaway excursion and subsequent ground loop.
The pilots impact with a buoy on takeoff which resulted in a nose-over.
The second pilots diverted attention while taxing which, resulted in his failure to maintain clearance from another airplane holding short of the runway.

The pilots improper landing flare which resulted in a hard landing following a partial loss of electrical power. Contributing to the accident was the pilots distraction and hampered visual function.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during the landing roll, which resulted in a ground-loop and collision with terrain.
The pilots failure to maintain clearance from the trees during a go-around.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during the landing roll which, resulted in a runway excursion and collision with a tree.
The pilot's improper fuel planning and improper in-flight decision-making, which resulted in a total loss of engine power due to fuel exhaustion and a subsequent hard landing on uneven terrain.
A loss of engine power due to fuel starvation and the pilot's mismanagement of the available fuel.
The airplanes impact with birds during approach.
The pilots failure to maintain airplane control during landing with a gusting crosswind which, resulted in a hard landing and collision with terrain.
The pilots failure to maintain adequate clearance from a parked helicopter while hovering to reposition for takeoff.
The loss of engine power due to carburetor icing and the pilots failure to utilize carburetor heat.
The pilots loss of airplane control during a go-around as it encountered wake turbulence from a slow hover taxiing helicopter.
The pilot's failure to maintain directional control during the landing roll.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control of the airplane during landing with a gusting crosswind that resulted in a runway excursion.
The pilots failure to maintain control during the landing with gusty wind.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during the landing roll.

Compañía aérea: BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF WESTERN MICHIGAN UNIVERSITY
Reporte: The pilots failure to ensure adequate terrain clearance during an approach. Contributing to the accident was the flight instructors delayed remedial action when the airplane descended too low after transitioning to a visual descent to the runway.
The windshear encounter on short final approach, which resulted in an excessive decent rate and ground impact.
The pilots inadequate flare and loss of directional control during landing which resulted in a runway excursion. Contributing to the accident was the instructors delayed remedial action.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during landing in cross wind conditions.
The student pilots loss of directional control while landing.
The pilot's failure to maintain directional control during the landing roll
The pilots decision to land on an unmaintained runway surface, which resulted in a loss of control and nose over.
An inflight collision with a bird, which resulted in substantial damage to the left wing.
The pilots failure to obtain a proper touch down location on a wet grass runway, resulting in a runway overrun and impact with terrain.
The pilots failure to maintain airplane control that resulted in an aerodynamic stall during approach and impact with terrain.
The pilots failure to maintain a proper glidepath which resulted in a collision with terrain.
The pilot's failure to maintain directional control during the landing roll.
The pilots failure to attain the proper touchdown point, which resulted in a runway overrun and collision with terrain.
The biplane pilots inadequate visual lookout, which resulted in an on-ground collision with another airplane while taxiing.
The pilot's failure to maintain control of the helicopter during a hover which, resulted in a collision with a hangar.
The pilots failure to maintain clearance from power lines during approach for landing.
The pilots failure to maintain stabilized lateral control during landing in gusty conditions which resulted in a dynamic rollover when the skids contacted the platform unevenly.
The pilots decision to land on the contaminated runway with previous reports of unfavorable braking action.
The pilot's failure to maintain a proper approach path in flat light conditions, which resulted in landing short of the runway and impact with terrain.
The solo student pilot's improper landing flare and bounced landing, which resulted in a runway excursion and impact with a parked vehicle and hanger.

The flight crews failure to verify the landing gear position prior to landing. Contributing to the accident was an overload in the landing gear motor electrical circuit which resulted in the circuit breaker opening, preventing the landing gear from extending.
The pilots fuel mismanagement, which resulted in a total loss of engine power due to fuel exhaustion and subsequent impact with trees during a forced landing.

The student pilot's unstabilized hover, which resulted in ground contact and a dynamic rollover. Contributing to the accident was the flight instructor's inadequate supervision of the student and his delayed remedial action.
The airplanes collision with a deer on the runway during landing.
The pilots improper landing flare which resulted in a bounced landing.
The pilots improper landing flare, and bounced landing, which resulted in a ground loop and runway excursion.
The pilots failure to maintain adequate clearance during landing on a rooftop helipad.
The failure of the pilot of the second aircraft to maintain a safe distance from the lead airplane while taxiing, which resulted in a ground collision.
The failure of the pilot of the second aircraft to maintain a safe distance from the lead airplane while taxiing, which resulted in a ground collision.
A total loss of engine power due to fuel exhaustion. Contributing to the accident was the pilot's inadequate preflight fuel inspection.
The pilots failure to maintain control of the airplane during taxi with a strong crosswind.
The flight instructors loss of airplane control during an aborted landing due to a wind shift, which resulted in an impact with a runway sign.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during landing with gusting wind.
The flight instructors failure to adequately correct for a loss of directional control during a simulated single engine approach.
The pilots delayed go-around decision following an encounter with a tailwind during landing, which resulted in an inability to climb and subsequent impact with trees.
The pilots failure to maintain pitch control during a go-around maneuver, which resulted in an aerodynamic stall and impact with the ground.
The student pilots incorrect landing flare, which resulted in a hard bounced landing and nose landing gear collapse.
The loss of directional control during the landing roll, due to missing hardware which resulted in the separation of the nose landing gear torque links.
The pilots failure to maintain helicopter control while on the ground when his attention was diverted, which resulted in a dynamic rollover.
The pilot did not maintain directional control during the landing roll resulting in a ground loop.
The pilot did not maintain directional control during landing, which led to a runway excursion and nose-over of the airplane.
The pilots improper landing flare which resulted in a hard landing and loss of airplane control.
The pilots inadequate compensation for the gusty crosswind wind conditions which resulted in a hard landing and subsequent nose gear collapse.
The student pilots failure to maintain lateral control and terrain clearance while hovering, and the flight instructors delayed remedial action which resulted in a dynamic rollover.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during takeoff in crosswind conditions which resulted in a loss of control and impact with terrain.
The flight instructors failure to maintain directional control with a quartering tailwind.
The fuelers improper action during the refueling process.
The failure of the right main landing gear brace rib for reasons that could not be determined based on available information.
The flight instructors inadequate supervision of the student pilot and the student pilots loss of directional control during landing, which resulted in a runway excursion.
The pilots failure to maintain sufficient clearance from the jet blast of a departing jet airplane.
The student pilot's improper landing flare and remedial action which resulted in a bounced landing.
Pilots failure to maintain clearance from a forklift while taxiing.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control while attempting to land in a crosswind.
The pilots failure to maintain airspeed and rotor rpm which resulted in a hard landing.

The student pilots application of excessive left brake during the landing roll, resulting in a loss of directional control and a runway excursion. The flight instructors inadequate remedial action was a factor in the accident.
The loss of directional control due to a fractured tailwheel steering linkage assembly.
Loss of engine power due to the throttle linkage becoming disconnected in flight due to improper maintenance.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during landing.

The student pilots excessive pitch during takeoff resulted in a loss of control and impact with terrain. Contributing was the students failure to relinquish the controls when ordered by the instructor.
The student pilots improper landing flare and the flight instructors delayed remedial response which resulted in an aerodynamic stall.
The pilots inability to maintain control in high wind conditions while repositioning during a landing attempt, which resulted in a loss of control and collision with terrain.
The pilots loss of control during landing.
The pilots inability to stop the airplane on the available runway, which resulted in a runway excursion and collision with an airport perimeter fence.
The pilots failure to maintain aircraft control during landing that resulted in an impact with terrain.
The failure to install the correct fuse in the landing gear circuit.
The pilots failure to maintain proper approach glide path, which resulted in a collision with trees.
The pilots failure to maintain clearance from the telephone pole during a low-level aerial application pass.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control of the airplane during takeoff.
The flight crew not maintaining lateral control of the helicopter during hovering operation which resulted in a dynamic rollover.
The pilots improper landing flare, which resulted in a hard, bounced landing and a subsequent loss of control.
The pilot's improper fuel planning, which resulted in a total loss of engine power due to fuel exhaustion, an emergency landing, and runway excursion.
The student pilots loss of control during a go-around and the delayed remedial action initiated by the flight instructor, which resulted in a runway excursion and collision with trees.
The multi-engine pilot's failure to maintain clearance from another airplane during taxi.
The multi-engine pilot's failure to maintain clearance from another airplane during taxi.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during takeoff.
The pilots poor pitch control during an aborted takeoff which resulted in a hard landing.
The pilots improper landing flare, which resulted in a bounced landing and the nose landing gear collapsing.
The pilots improper landing flare which resulted in a hard landing.
The pilots failure to monitor rotor disk speed on takeoff, which resulted in blade flapping and the main rotor blades striking the gyroplanes tail assembly.
The student pilots failure to maintain airspeed and yaw control of the airplane during an aborted takeoff, which resulted in an aerodynamic stall and impact with the ground.
The pilots failure to maintain clearance from a power line pole while preparing for a low-level aerial application pass.
The pilot's loss of helicopter control on approach to land due to a settling with power condition, which resulted in a hard landing.
The pilots failure to attain proper flare during landing, resulting in a bounced landing.
The flight instructors failure to adequately monitor the pilot flying, which resulted in a nose-wheel first hard landing.
The pilots failure to maintain clearance from obstructed terrain during takeoff.
The student pilot not maintaining directional control during landing which resulted in a runway excursion.
The pilots failure to maintain control during the landing with a quartering tailwind.
The pilots improper landing flare, which resulted in a bounced landing and subsequent nose landing gear collapse.
The pilot's encounter with sinking air conditions that resulted in a loss of lift and a subsequent loss of control.
The pilots premature retraction of the landing gear during a go-around, which resulted in a gear up landing.

The pilots failure to maintain directional control during takeoff which resulted in an impact with terrain. Contributing to the accident was the pilots momentary distraction from conflicting boat traffic.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during takeoff in gusting wind conditions which resulted in a loss of control and impact with the water.
The pilots failure to maintain directional control during landing, which resulted in a runway excursion and substantial damage.

The pilots failure to maintain directional control during a landing attempt, which resulted in a ground loop and collision with terrain. Contributing to the accident was the absence of an airspeed indicator due to an alternator failure.
The pilots failure to maintain proper airspeed while landing in gusting winds, which resulted in a hard landing and a runway excursion.

The pilots rapid reduction of collective following an in-flight loss of control while lifting from a dolly resulting in a hard landing. Contributing to the loss of control was the pilots likely inadequate left anti-torque control pedal input during initial liftoff.
The pilots improper fuel management that resulted in fuel exhaustion and a loss of engine power.
The student pilots improper landing flare, which resulted in a hard landing. Also causal was the flight instructors inadequate remedial action.
The pilot under instructions improper landing flare, and the flight instructors delayed remedial action.
The student pilots inadequate flare resulting in a loss of airplane control during landing with gusting wind conditions.
The pilots excessive use of brakes which resulted in a nose-over.
